Empires & Puzzles Shoggo Review: 4-Star Epic Dark Purple from Cultist Family

Is Shoggo a hidden gem in the Shadow Summon or just a headache waiting to happen? We explore this 4-Star hero's risky Insanity mechanics and whether the massive Cultist family bonus is enough to save him from the bench.
Shoggo: The Tentacled Lantern Bearer of Chaos
Shoggo: The Keeper of the Lantern... and Your Sanity?

Shoggo is a 4-Star Dark (Purple) hero introduced with the Shadow Summon event in early 2025. Belonging to the Cultist family, he brings a mix of AoE damage, buff blocking, and the controversial Insanity mechanic to the table. While his appearance suggests he might know the secrets of the deep, his gameplay suggests he might just be confused about which team he is on. He operates as a "fire-and-forget" hero—or perhaps "fire-and-regret"—due to the hefty penalty he inflicts on himself after casting his special.

Shoggo's design is delightfully creepy, fitting perfectly with the Lovecraftian "Shadows of the Deep" theme. He appears to be a hunched, robed figure—possibly not even human underneath—burdened by netting and ropes, clutching a glowing lantern. The purple tentacles emerging from his back are a nice touch, signaling his connection to the deep entities. The art conveys a sense of damp, dark madness, which is exactly what you want from a Cultist. It is a solid design that stands out among the more traditional warriors and wizards, looking like he just walked off the set of a horror movie involving a very bad day at the docks.

When looking at Shoggo's raw stats, you might initially be unimpressed. With a base Power of 712, Attack of 711, and Defense of 701, he sits noticeably lower than many modern 4-star heroes released in late 2025, who often push towards 800 Power and significantly higher base stats (e.g., Breca or Rafeeq).
However, Shoggo has a trick up his sleeve: the

. This bonus provides a massive percentage increase to Defense and Health for just having him on the team (even alone). This means his "real" in-match stats are significantly higher than what is shown on the card, allowing him to soak up much more damage than his base numbers imply. He is deceptively tanky thanks to this mechanic, which was likely designed to curb raw power creep inflation on the card face while keeping him competitive in battle.
, is a double-edged sword wrapped in a wet fishing net.
He deals 250% damage to all enemies at Average speed. This is respectable for a 4-star, softening up the enemy team. More importantly, he applies
to all enemies for 4 turns. In formats like Buff Booster tournaments, this is a game-winning effect.
The 10 Insanity inflicted on enemies is negligible. It is a nice flavor text, but rarely impactful.

This 55 Insanity is the deal-breaker for many. Insanity acts as a percentage chance to reverse the targeting of a special skill. With 55 Insanity, the next time Shoggo fires, there is a greater than 50% chance he will cast his damage and debuffs on

. Essentially, unless you have a way to aggressively heal him (reducing insanity by 10 per heal) or cleanse him (if the mechanic allows, though Insanity is usually persistent), he is often a "one-and-done" hero. You fire him once to block buffs, and then he becomes a liability.
Average. He requires 10 tiles to charge.

250% to all enemies. With a base attack of 711, this hits reasonably hard for a 4-star, likely dealing around 250-350 damage per hero depending on defense, for a total output of ~1200-1500 damage across a full team.

The 55 Insanity on self means a 55% chance of friendly fire on the next cast. Conversely, the 10 Insanity on enemies means only a 10% chance they will mess up. The risk-to-reward ratio here is heavily skewed against the player.
4 turns is a generous duration for Average speed, providing a substantial window of opportunity to attack without worrying about enemy defensive buffs.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
bonus is Shoggo's saving grace. Unlike most family bonuses that require multiple unique heroes, this one scales down to just one.
bonus. A 20% boost to health and defense makes Shoggo incredibly durable for a 4-star, effectively giving him 5-star durability in a 4-star arena.
Shoggo does not possess any passive skills. This is a missed opportunity, as a passive to mitigate the self-insanity or provide a small benefit when insane would have made his kit much more cohesive.
is a solid, if boring, choice. Combined with his family bonus and natural bulk, it ensures he sticks around. However, given his self-sabotaging nature, you might sometimes wonder if you
him to survive long enough to fire a second time.
Released during the "Insanity" era of 2025, Shoggo represents a design experiment where high stats (via family bonus) and strong effects are balanced by significant drawbacks (Self-Insanity).

His base stats are kept artificially low to account for the family bonus. Mechanics-wise, "Hit All + Buff Block" is a classic utility combination (seen in heroes like Sabina C2 or Waddles). However, modern 4-star Toons and Construct heroes often offer similar power levels without the crippling downside of a 55% failure rate on subsequent casts.
Shoggo is a niche hero. He is not a staple for general raiding or wars. His home is almost exclusively in
, where the value of blocking buffs outweighs the risk of him going crazy later in the match. Outside of that, he struggles to compete with safer, more consistent options.
As of this review, Shoggo does not have a costume.
Since Shoggo is a Druid, you have the option to make him a minion-spawning nuisance.
Maximizes the benefit of his massive Family Bonus. Keeps him alive to cast his special at least once, which is his primary job (applying Buff Immunity).
His damage output will be mediocre.
Increases the damage of his 250% AoE hit.
If he succumbs to Insanity and hits your own team, he will hit them harder.
path is recommended. Shoggo's main utility is the Buff Immunity. You want him to survive long enough to cast it. If he survives longer and casts again, well, good luck with the coin flip.
Blocks new buffs for 4 turns, which shuts down many popular tanks and supports.
The Cultist family bonus grants huge survivability, making him one of the sturdiest 4-stars available.
AoE damage is always useful for softening teams or finishing off weakened foes.
The 55 Insanity inflicted on self is a massive liability. It effectively discourages using his special more than once per match unless you have very specific cleansers or healers.
Without the family bonus active (e.g., if blocked or in specific scenarios), his stats are subpar.
You cannot trust him in a long fight.
His best environment. Blocking buffs prevents the enemy from gaining the tournament attack boost.
He can fire quickly, but the risk of firing repeatedly and hitting your own team increases. Use with caution.
The key to using Shoggo is mitigating his drawback or ending the fight before it matters.
Shoggo - C2 Li Xiu - C2 Caedmon - C2 Cyprian - Goldie
Use Shoggo to apply the buff block early. The rest of the team provides dispels, damage, and reflects to secure the win before Shoggo needs to recharge.

Insanity can be lowered by 10 each time the hero is healed directly by a special skill. Running Shoggo with multiple healers (like Rigard, Kiril, etc.) can help scrub the insanity off him, theoretically allowing him to fire safely again. However, this is a lot of work for a 4-star payoff.
Status Ailment blockers (e.g., Garnet, Vanda) prevent him from applying his debuffs. Monks/Clerics can resist the insanity or buff block.
Do not pair him with heroes who rely on buffs if you think he might misfire and block your own team (though Insanity reverses targeting, so he would damage your team and block

If you pull Shoggo early, his durability (thanks to the family bonus) makes him a solid tank or flank for your map progression and early raids. The Buff Block is a powerful tool against bosses who buff themselves. Just be careful in long fights; if he starts glowing purple with insanity, maybe hold off on using his skill a second time.

Shoggo is likely a "pass" for most developed rosters. He does not displace C2 Sabina or other premier dispellers/blockers. The self-insanity is too high a price for "okay" damage. Unless you are collecting for the museum or desperately need a dark buff blocker for tournaments, he is not a priority for Limit Breaks or Emblems.
The community reaction to Shoggo was lukewarm at best.
"10% insanity is mediocre just like any other released epic hero... Can’t really see this character pull anything off against a team full of 4
Another summarized the frustration with the Insanity mechanic:
"Don’t like it gives only 10 insanity to all while he himself takes 55. The buff blocker is useful but C2-Sabina does that without getting 55%
Poll results were harsh, with many voting that he is "Not really" worth summoning and "Zero" copies are useful to keep. The consensus is that while the artwork is fantastic, the kit is confused.

Shoggo feels like a prank gift. The wrapping paper (Family Bonus stats) is expensive and durable, but the gift inside (Self-Insanity) explodes in your face. He is a hero with 5-star survivability and a 1-star sense of loyalty. While he shines in the specific niche of Buff Booster tournaments, for general play, he is simply too risky.
If you max him, do it for the family bonus stats or the cool art, but don't be surprised if he decides to help the enemy team just when you need him most.
Keep one for Buff Booster tournaments if you lack other options, but do not prioritize him over reliable staples.
